distributional 0.3.2

The Pareto distribution

Source: R/dist_pareto.R
dist_pareto.Rd

dist_pareto(shape, scale)

Arguments

shape, scale

parameters. Must be strictly positive.

See also

actuar::Pareto

Examples

dist <- dist_pareto(shape = c(10, 3, 2, 1), scale = rep(1, 4))
dist
#> <distribution[4]>
#> [1] Pareto(10, 1) Pareto(3, 1)  Pareto(2, 1)  Pareto(1, 1) 

mean(dist)
#> [1] 0.1111111 0.5000000 1.0000000       Inf
variance(dist)
#> [1] 0.0154321 0.7500000       Inf       NaN
support(dist)
#> <support_region[4]>
#> [1] [0,Inf] [0,Inf] [0,Inf] [0,Inf]
generate(dist, 10)
#> [[1]]
#>  [1] 0.054060594 0.156092000 0.063877745 0.180041281 0.003487678 0.263516540
#>  [7] 0.237885411 0.021603247 0.017172319 0.135952086
#> 
#> [[2]]
#>  [1] 1.0093071 0.7965555 1.1291464 1.2530014 0.3831021 0.1628967 0.1370831
#>  [8] 0.2715829 0.5857067 0.1368183
#> 
#> [[3]]
#>  [1] 0.02518136 0.21949545 1.99270713 0.43433379 0.30083768 0.20923739
#>  [7] 4.16248608 1.89834252 0.16971046 0.31302114
#> 
#> [[4]]
#>  [1]  4.57765760 20.08839709  0.85274252  0.40410827  0.42583348  0.13243305
#>  [7]  1.23196306  0.69728216  0.83526601  0.04814121
#> 

density(dist, 2)
#> [1] 5.645029e-05 3.703704e-02 7.407407e-02 1.111111e-01
density(dist, 2, log = TRUE)
#> [1] -9.782150 -3.295837 -2.602690 -2.197225

cdf(dist, 4)
#> [1] 0.9999999 0.9920000 0.9600000 0.8000000

quantile(dist, 0.7)
#> [1] 0.1279449 0.4938016 0.8257419 2.3333333
